Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Mathematics, Engineering, and Physics (MEP) Scholars program at Jacksonville University is contributing well-prepared individuals to the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) workforce by providing an educational experience that emphasizes student discovery. This program is designed to increase enrollment of students, including those from underrepresented groups, and improve retention of scholars through graduation or transfer to an affiliated institution in engineering-related disciplines. The project can serve as a model for similar institutions, particularly those that utilize a 3 + 2 program with affiliated universities for students to earn an engineering degree.

The project is recruiting annual cohorts of students based on academic ability and financial need and supporting them by the development of a Residential Learning Community (RLC), faculty mentors, tutoring, peer study groups, college survival skills training, and career development. The program is collecting information on how an RLC works as well as how the systemic implementation of the numerous support structures impacts the retention and graduation of STEM majors. Women and underrepresented minorities are being targeted in recruitment and retained via the social and academic support structures of an RLC. The program is being assessed based on enrollment, mid-term and final grades, attendance at extracurricular functions, career plans, resiliency, engagement of faculty and students, learning motivation, and learning strategies. Outcomes and knowledge gained are being broadly disseminated.

The participation by scholars in project-based courses, mathematical modeling contests, and enrollment in paired courses enables them to discover the connections between physics and mathematics. The scholars are being encouraged to participate in an annual mathematical modeling competition, undergraduate research, and internships with local government and industry partners. Support structures are scheduled within the targeted majors to deliver maximum impact to each student and to equip each student to succeed. Mentoring provides feedback and guidance and grounds students in their chosen disciplines. Undergraduate research, internships, and career development solidifies their learning and prepares them professionally. To ensure best practices in STEM teaching, a Learning Community (LC) is being created for the MEP faculty and tutors. Faculty and tutors are participating in workshops and regular meetings to discuss best practices in STEM education, teaching strategies, and the progress of the program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Jacksonville University (JU)  created the Mathematics, Engineering, and Physics Scholars (MEP-Scholars) program to enable academically talented students with financial need to complete a Science, Technology, Engineering or Mathematics (STEM) degree and enter the workforce or graduate school. The MEP-Scholar program actively funded 27 students through 4-year Bachelor of Science degrees in the following majors: Electrical engineering, Mechanical engineering, Computing Science, Cybersecurity, Information systems, Mathematics, or Physics. This coupled with the initiation of the BS Engineering program resulted in a 49% increase in student enrollment in these engineering and engineering-related fields at Jacksonville University. The project had as a second goal the improved enrollment and degree completion of underrepresented groups in engineering-related disciplines. The active recruitment of students with academic ability and financial need resulted in substantial shift in the racial demographics of STEM majors. At the start of the project only 20% of the students in STEM majors self-reported as Black. By the conclusion of the project 36% of the STEM students self-reported as Black. The 16% increase was accompanied by an increase in overall numbers of students in the STEM majors and was a noticeable shift in the diversity of the affected departments. A similar goal to increase the number of women, traditionally under-represented in the engineering related STEM fields, was less successful. The percentage of women in the targeted majors remained very consistent at 17%. 

Program elements  including individual faculty mentors, tutoring, peer study groups, college survival skills training,and career development were also implemented to provide support for students during their Jacksonville University education. The scholars were encouraged to participate in an annual mathematical modeling competition, undergraduate research, and internships with local government and industry partners. A university-wide graduation requirement for experiential learning assisted with the attractiveness of internships and undergraduate research activities as these satisfied the requirement. All 27 students in the MEP Scholars program completed either an internship or undergraduate research project. Several students presented their research at regional and national meetings of professional societies.

The sense of community was strengthened through academic and social activities. Annual discussion of recent movies related to the majors formed a needed social release during the final weeks of each term.  The movie nights also allowed exploration of social issues related to marginalized groups in STEM fields. Two such films were "Imitation Game" and "Hidden Figures". Students also had annual field trips to local industries to showcase potential careers and applications of engineering, mathematics, and computer science in the NE Florida region. 

Outcomes from the graduating students include commisions in the US Navy, particularly in the prestigious nuclear program, graduate school for business and computer science, employment with engineering and software development companies. The placement rate for graduates from the program is 90% in graduate education or employment in field.
